title: Three days ago I talked about IQ with a high school friend of mine, he graduated from college while I dropped out of high school. he told me not to be surprised that my IQ is 85. I was silent. What did you think he meant? - Quora

response.answer_text: It sounds to me as though he might have been less than polite. But, he might have been joking or there could be some other mis- intended reason for the comment. Let' s assume he is right, I am not for one second suggesting he might be, but let's just say he was. When I was 18 years of age I was tested & scored coincidentally 85. That was before I obtained Craft skills. Long before I went to university. Long before I went back to university. Before I'd acquired a lot of life skills & professional career, which at a younger age, wouldn't have even dreamed about. Twenty five years later, the test was re-applied (serruptitiously in what is known as a 'blind' experiment) by a chartered Psychologist. I scored nearly double 160. So even if he was right & it was true (which I honestly do not believe), IQ is not fixed, it is fluid. After a person has acquired life skills, their IQ likely be much higher. My advice: move on, high school is history. That was then, this is now. BELIEVE in yourself: Go back to college & prove him wrong! A Degree is not for people who have high IQ's, but through undergraduate study , one's IQ grows. Peace & All Good

Your friend is under two impressions: Any person, even a trained person, can estimate someone’s intelligence by interacting with them sociallyYou are not very intelligent, at least in a measurable wayLook, for all I know, you might be intelligent or an idiot, but I can assure you that #1 is false. Generally speaking, ignore data and discussion of IQ. IQ is NOT what matters. OQ. Three days ago I talked about IQ with a high school friend of mine, he graduated from college while I dropped out of high school. he told me not to be surprised that my IQ is 85. I was silent. What did you think he meant?
